frameDefinitions: A Host provides a temporary Residence for a Lodger.

An Agent is involved in an activity whose degree of success is dependent on a parameter of the action matching a particular set of values of a continuous variable or variables (e.g. quantity, location, time).
A particular piece of Information is evaluated for its accuracy.
Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer being aware (or not being aware) of the difference between two Phenomena, which may be expressed jointly or disjointly.
A Cognizer construes an Item as belonging to a certain Category.
frameExamples: We <t>housed</t> her in our home for a while.
The Longview Rangefinder is <t>accurate</t> to within one foot per hundred yards .
Is your reputation at risk due to <t>incorrect</t> information?

A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
It is very difficult for people to visually <t>distinguish</t> between living and non-living things from such a great distance .
You 've already <t>stereotyped</t> me as a bimbo, have n't you?
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Host</fen> is the individual (or group of individuals) that own or control the <fen>Residence</fen> and allow the  <fen>Lodger</fen> to temporarily stay there.
The <fen>Lodger</fen> is the individual who is given permission to lodge in the <fen>Residence</fen>.
The location controlled by the <fen>Host</fen> which the <fen>Lodger</fen> stays at temporarily.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Host</fen> provides a Residence to the <fen>Lodger</fen>
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the <fen>Host</fen> provides a temporary <fen>Residence</fen>.
The individual who tries to interact with the <fen>Target</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Means</fen> by which the <fen>Agent</fen> attempts to hit a <fen>Target_value</fen>.
How closely the expected or actual location that the <fen>Instrument</fen> interacts with corresponds to the <fen>Target_value</fen>.
The object manipulated by the <fen>Agent</fen> in order to interact with the <fen>Target</fen>.
Expected or actual deviation from the <fen>Target_value</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when something hits or misses.
The place where the <fen>Agent</fen> manages or fails to interact with the <fen>Target</fen>.
The <fen>Information</fen> matches or does not match the facts of the world.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the agent who holds the correct/incorrect information.
The event which communicates the <fen>Information</fen>.
The Topic about which the Source has accurate information.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Information</fen> or the <fen>Source</fen> is correct.
This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists
The cognizer is the person (or other sentient being) who potentially determines that two Phenomena are distinct from each other. It is normally expressed as an External Argument:

The phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed as separate constituents. When they are, one is typically expressed as an NP Object, and the other as a PP Complement headed by <ment>from</ment>:
See Phenomenon_1, above. The phenomenon expressed less prominently as a PP complement is called <fen>Phenomenon_2</fen>:
Both phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed jointly by the same constituent:

This is a property that is potentially used by the Cognizer to distinguish one phenomenon from another. It is normally expressed as a PP headed by a preposition such as <ment>from</ment>, <ment>by</ment>, or <ment>on the basis of</ment>:
This is the person who performs an act of categorization. Typically, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument.
This is the entity which is construed or treated by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> as being an instance of a particular <fen>Category</fen>. Typically, the <fen>Item</fen> is expressed as an Object.

This frame element expresses a general type or class of which the <fen>Item</fen> is considered an instance. Typically, it is expressed in a prepositional phrase headed by <ment>as</ment> or <ment>under</ment>.

This frame element expresses properties of the <fen>Item</fen> which is used as a basis for categorization. <fen>Criteria</fen> are the general dimensions along which <fen>Item</fen>s can potentially differ from one another and hence, fall into different <fen>Category</fen>s. For example, a paint sample can be classified <ment>by color</ment> or <ment>by finish (matte or gloss)</ment>; if they are classified by color, one can be classified <ment>as orange</ment> and another <ment>as red</ment>. The <fen>Criteria</fen> role is typically expressed as a PP headed by <ment>by</ment>, or as a complex PP of the form <ment>on the basis of...</ment>:
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The mailman</fex> is very exact about addresses -- he has to be .
For this they would need a thermometer accurate <fex>to within a microkelvin</fex>.
<fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
<fex>The teacher</fex> couldn't distinguish one child from the other.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat from Kim.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat <fex>from Kim</fex>.
The coach could distinguish the twins <fex>by their hair</fex>.
<fex>Kim</fex> categorized the books under fiction. <fex>Kim</fex> categorized them on the basis of genre.
The students were categorized <fex>on the basis of their test scores</fex>.
<fex>20 years ago</fex> people would consider this as nothing unusual
